title: Touch Tank Feeding, Science in 3D and Shark Smarts at Museum of Coastal Carolina | News | newsargus.com
text:
The Museum of Coastal Carolina’s summer program schedule goes into full swing with new virtual reality programming, a look into the lives of pollinators, helping little ones discover animals that live around us and much more.
Here’s a complete breakdown of what’s on the schedule at the Museum during the month of June:
Touch Tank Feeding
Monday, Wednesday and Friday at 11 a.m. With staff and trained volunteer assistance, gently touch the sea creatures living in the Museum’s Touch Tank and watch trained volunteers feed the animals.
Science in 3D
Monday, Wednesday and Friday at 1 p.m. Strap on a virtual reality headset and explore a different virtual world each day.
- Monday — Honeybees. Get an up-close look at bees as you buzz through a beehive. Learn about the role each bee plays in the hive and see how bees make honey through the lens of virtual reality.
- Wednesday — Hurricane Maria. Dive into the eye of Hurricane Maria, track windspeed and rainfall, and learn what to do when there is a hurricane. After traveling through the eye of the hurricane, learn about hurricane preparedness through fun supplementary activities.
- Friday — Ocean Rift. Dive into a vivid underwater world full of life including dolphins, sharks, turtles, sea snakes, rays, whales, manatees, sea lions and even prehistoric animals! Swim through a variety of virtual ocean habitats and learn fun facts about an array of sea creatures.
Creation Station
Monday and Friday at 3 p.m. Get in touch with your creative side during our Creation Station craft program Mondays and Fridays at 3 p.m. Each day will feature a different coastal or nautical-themed craft.
Sea Tales
Tuesday at 11 a.m. Listen to stories starring animals or exhibits displayed at the Museum and complete interactive crafts or science activities based on each story:
- June 17 — The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach — When a group of caterpillars scamper up a tree to metamorphosize, one of them is still learning about this whole transformation thing. Who knew that with a little time and patience, he could become a beautiful butterfly? But the two-week wait inside his chrysalis feels interminable. “Can I get a comic book?” “What if I need the bathroom?” “Anyone want to play a game?” His fellow caterpillars all tell him to be patient and let nature take its course, but the waiting is just so hard. Can he do it? Find out as this hilarious tale is read t and make a butterfly craft.
- June 24 — The Bat by Elise Gravel — The Bat covers habitat (bats live everywhere except Antarctica!), species (there are over 1,200 kinds of bats), echolocation, hibernation (bats hibernate just like bears!), conservation (don’t disturb a sleeping bat!) and much more. Although silly and off-the-wall, The Bat contains factual information that will both amuse and teach at the same time. This fun story will be read and participants can make their own hanging bats.
Sea Turtle Adventures
Tuesday at 1 p.m. Sea turtles are frequent visitors to the North Carolina coast, with several individuals nesting on beaches from the Outer Banks to Ocean Isle Beach. Learn all about the species of sea turtles in N.C. and what you can do to help protect sea turtles and make a clay turtle to take home.
Tidal Treasures
Tuesday at 3 p.m. A variety of seashells can be found on the beach. Discover more about these “tidal treasures,” learn what animals create them, and how to identify some of the most common shells found on N.C. beaches. Put your ID skills to the test through a fun shell sorting and matching activity.
Beach Basics
Wednesday at 3 p.m. This is an introduction to common beach creatures and beach safety! Test your ocean IQ by learning about sea creatures such as jellyfish, sea stars, sharks, and sea turtles and discover how to keep them and yourself safe while having fun in the sun. Beach safety tips, including what to do when swimming alone and how to help someone in the water, will be given through interactive discussion. The program will end by making a fun sea bottle craft.
Shark Smarts
Thursday at 11 a.m. How many sharks live off the coast of NC? Do sharks really eat people? Find out in this fun, interactive program! This program will look at the amazing world of sharks and what makes them unique. Learn about shark anatomy, diets, and predators, and bust myths and misconceptions about sharks. It will also discuss some “shark smarts” that will keep you and others safe while you have fun in the sun. At the end of the program participants will make a fun shark craft, designing our own shark jaws.
Swamp Sleuths
Thursday at 1 p.m. This visitor favorite program is back with a new mystery! Learn about the diversity of life in the Green Swamp in this CSI program that is fun for all ages. Someone has destroyed Rhonda the Virginia Rail’s nest and we need your help to find out who did it! Become a wildlife detective by identifying animal tracks and scat and analyzing trail camera images. Then compile the evidence and narrow down the suspects to put your swamp sleuthing skills to the test.
Pollinator Pals
Thursday at 3 p.m. Pollinators come in all shapes and sizes from bees and butterflies to birds, bats, moths, and wasps. Through visuals and interactive discussion, learn about pollination, the importance of pollinators, and what we can do to protect pollinators. Explore activity stations to learn more about each type of pollinator and what makes them unique.
Snakes Alive
Thursday at 6 p.m. Meet a variety of snakes up close and personal in one of the museum’s longest running programs.
